results.title: Light in the darkness
results.creator_credit: K Khandpur, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: Today there are more than 50 schools for the blind in India where children as well as adults receive education and training. The Central Braille Printing Press at Dehra Dun is dedicated to serving the sightless. The training centre for the adult blind, also located at Dehra Dun, is one of the most important centres of its kind in the country. Weaving is among the principal technical trades taught.

results.title: Light illumination and its measurement
results.brief_description: Illustrates the common sources of artificial light and explains their operation. Describes in detail the measurement of light, indicating luminous intensity, luminous flux and illumination. Explains and demonstrates such basic terms as candle power, lumen and foot-candle.

results.title: Light control through polarisation
results.creator_credit: Loucks and Norling Studios and Moviegram Films
results.brief_description: Sketches the nature of light waves, the focusing of a light beam, the spectrum and the use of color filters. Diagrams are employed to explain the theory of polarisation.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates the swimming strokes best adapted to life-saving: how to approach a swimmer in difficulties, breaking holds, carries, methods of rescuing by boat and by ring buoy, and the Schafer method of resuscitation.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film, which includes a demonstration of land drill by the Southsea Police Lifeguard Corps (England), shows in detail the various methods needed for rescuing a docile person, a turbulent person, somebody really violent, and a tired but clear-headed swimmer. The sidestroke method of rescue, the surface dive necessary if the subject has sunk, and the use of artificial respiration are also demonstrated.

results.title: Lifeclimb
results.creator_credit: Stan Zundell, Pyramid Films and Stan Zundell Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary in which 64 year old Stan Zundell describes the manner in which he has faced the difficulties and challenges of aging. Shows how he continually challenges himself with rigorous physical activity, increasing his abilities as he struggles to achieve his goals.

results.title: Life story of the paramecium
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The physical characteristics, life functions, adaptation to environment and means of reproduction of the paramecium, a one-celled animal or protozoa which performs all life functions in a single cell. Some, the volvox, live in colonies and perform special functions, making it possible for new organisms to develop and function. An understanding of the protozoa provides the basis for a better understanding of the functions of all animals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Life sense: our lives through animal eyes. Part 2
results.creator_credit: John Downer, BBC-TV and Lionheart TV International
results.brief_description: How do we appear to the animals that share our lives? From the two million dustmites that inhabit our beds every night to the Macaque monkey picking 800 coconuts every day - animals are an integral part of human life. As well as providing companionship and food, they live on our bodies and influence the climate and the air that we breathe. But what do they see? What is the influence of our actions on their behaviour? This unique six-part BBC TV series provides the answers using stunning and innovative film and video techniques to truly show how our lives appear through animal eyes. Narrated by Andrew Sachs and contains the last three episodes - “Life and soul”, “Human life” and “Life in the balance”.

results.title: Life on the western marshes
results.brief_description: Each spring North America’s wild ducks and geese leave for their northern breeding ranges. Most of them land in the Canadian northwest, where, by June, the marshes shelter thousands of broods. Despite their rapid growth, only three out of every ten ducklings survive to learn to fly. Attacked by animal and bird predators, poisoned in scores by bacteria in low waters, threatened on the ground by magpies, ground squirrels, and gophers, and from the air by crows, yet the greatest danget to ducklings in man’s misuse of natural resources, for while times the watersheds flood the breading areas, at other times the level of water is allowed to sink dangerously low. ‘Ducks Unlimited’, an organisation formed by both sportsmen and farmers, helped by the on-the-spot community co-operation, is carrying out measures to preserve wildfowl from the various threats to their existence.
